Let $c>0$. If $x$ is sufficiently large then does there exist $n\leq x$ such that the values of $\phi(n+k)$ are all distinct for $1\leq k\leq (\log x)^c$, where $\phi$ is the Euler totient function?



Erd\H{o}s, Pomerenace, and S\'{a}rk\"{o}zy \cite{EPS87} proved that if $\phi(n+k)$ are all distinct for $1\leq k\leq K$ then\[K \leq \frac{n}{\exp(c(\log n)^{1/3})}\]for some constant $c>0$.

See [945] for the analogous problem with the divisor function.




References


[EPS87] Erd\H{o}s, Paul and Pomerance, Carl and S\'ark\"ozy, Andr\'as, On locally repeated values of certain arithmetic functions.
{III}. Proc. Amer. Math. Soc. (1987), 1--7.
